title: Orbital motion - elliptical orbit with points ABC

Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A moon is moving clockwise in an elliptical orbit around a planet, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> are the locations where the moon is closest and farthest from the planet, respectively, and Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> is equidistant from points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>. The distances from the planet to points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> are <math alttext="r sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="r sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>, and <math alttext="r sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, respectively.

(a) Figures <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> each show the planet and a portion of the moon’s orbit, including points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.

i. In Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, draw arrows to indicate the direction of the moon’s velocity at both points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>. If the velocity is zero at either point, write “<math alttext="v equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>” next to the appropriate dot.

ii. In Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, draw arrows to indicate the direction of the moon’s acceleration at both points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>. If the acceleration is zero at either point, write “<math alttext="a, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>” next to the appropriate dot.

The moon’s mass is <math alttext="lowercase m sub uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>M</mtext></msub></math>. At Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, its speed is <math alttext="v sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math> and it is a distance <math alttext="r sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math> from the planet. At Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, its speed is <math alttext="v sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> and it is a distance <math alttext="r sub B equals, five halves r sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math> from the planet, as indicated in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. There is a <math alttext="53 degree" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mn>53</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math> angle between the line joining the planet and Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and the line joining the planet and Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>.
(b) Starting with the conservation of angular momentum, derive an expression for the moon’s speed <math alttext="v sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> when it is at Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="lowercase m sub uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>M</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="v sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="r sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing either a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference book.

(c) On the axes in Figure <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the moon’s kinetic energy as a function of its distance <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> from the planet. <math alttext="r sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="r sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> are the distances from the planet to points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>A</mtext></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>, respectively.
Notes:

Your graph should only include distances attained by the moon for the orbit shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

On the vertical axis, the quantity <math alttext="K sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math> is equal to <math alttext="one half times lowercase m sub uppercase M, end sub, times v sub A, end sub, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>M</mtext></msub><msup><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

(d) Indicate whether the graph you drew in part (c) is consistent with the velocity and acceleration you indicated for Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> in part (a).

_____ It is consistent.          _____ It is not consistent.

Justify your answer.
